column1: What will be the Estimated CO2 (carbon dioxide) Daily Global Seasonal Cycle value for 1 December 2020, according to NOAA's Earth System Research Laboratory?
column4: More than 414.00 ppm but less than 416.00 ppm
column5: ['Less than 412.00 ppm', 'Between 412.00 ppm and 414.00 ppm, inclusive', 'More than 414.00 ppm but less than 416.00 ppm', '416.00 ppm or more']
column6: ['Environment']
@mmunsell 414.1042
It will rise above 414 today, and because these values are output from a model that smooths observations, it will not decline again until next spring.

Currently the value sits at 413.94 in the cycle column and has been increasing by 0.04 ppm for the last week. This combined with the delta combined to last years makes it likely that it will be above 414.00 ppm
It has only been above 414 once in the last week and twice above 413.5, so the odds of it being at 414.1 or higher on Tuesday are not that great.
413,91 Boom goes the dynamite.

The DGSC is at 413.83 now (23/11) and rising steadily with about 0.04 ppm daily over the past 14 days. At this rate, the estimated CO2 daily global seasonal cycle value should cross the 414.00 ppm value in 5 days. The DGSC value should fall into the third bin around 4 days before the 1 December deadline.
It looks like the projection is still aiming to be around 414.15 ppm so I will increase the likelyhood

Updating to confirm rationale. To hit second bucket growth integers over the next 8 days would need to dive from 0.04 to an average of 0.02125: a freak dip not commensurate with previous years or this year's relative high.

Looks like ordered categorical scoring will be a benefit on this question. I ave been at 413.95, now at 414.1 since nov 2. I assumed .04 as low bound of rate of increase in te final month. Now it is .04. Rate and if steady we come in at 414.1. If a .03 rate well that is 414.01. Now we will be looking at the differnce between precision and accuracy.

There is an amount of .69ppm outstanding to cross the threshold between the second bin and the third bin in 2020. In 2019, after 14 November's value, the time series added .72ppm until 01 December 2019. In a disruptive year statistically, this puts us ahead three days of cyclical CO2 emissions versus last year as of today, which in consequence means the value will almost surely be higher than 414.00ppm on resolution.

Just realised that <412ppm and >416ppm are impossible with the smoothed seasonal trend rather than spot measurements. Doh! Should have noticed that months ago. Looks like it's going to be on or just over 414ppm.

I looked at last years value which was 411.41 ppm. I then compared the amount by which a value increased from the previous year and was able to create distributions, which are generally in the range of 2-3 ppm per year.

NOAA seem to be constantly revising upwards, so as of now, the next 22 days need to average a rise of only 0.035 to reach 414. Over the last few previous years daily integers have dipped to 0.03 for just a few days before rising back to 0.04. Unless we experience a rogue 11 day trough at 0.03ppm per day or a shorter trough where the daily growth integer dips to 0.02, est ppm on Dec 1st will be 414 or above.

The data from Mauna Loa showed 411.07 ppm for Dec 1, 2019 On average the increase _thus far_ has been around 2-3 ppm per year If we assume an increase of approximately 2.5 or 2.75, then it will be very likely that it is less than 414 ppm.

Nov 4 is 412.3. So .04 per day for 27 days puts it at 413.98. .04 is a low bound for daily cycle so it does indeed look like the final value at close of dec 1 will be above 414.

Update from previous rationale: NOAA figures have been adjusted back and forth over the last couple of days, but if today’s reading for yesterday is correct at 412.9, readings only need to hit two more days of growth at 0.05 and the rest to hit 0.04 for ppm to reach 414 by Dec 1st. Since consolidated daily readings haven’t yet dipped to 0.04 and are only just starting to dip from 0.06 to 0.05, it seems even more unlikely to me that they will dip below the 27 day average of 0.04074074 necessary to reach 414. Given the excessive high this year and grievous damage to global carbon sinks, I see no reason to expect greater slowing than usual.

Paradigm shift. Somewhere in August /Sept the older data changed biasing it higher. That is the older values were restated at some later date. I failed to refresh ALL my data at each forecast - foolishly appending new data to old. Lesson learned. ALWAYS refresh all your data from the source. Do Not assume "old" data will be static and not be restated as this was. I've paid the Brier price for this shortcut.

Reducing confidence by a decent amount. Initially I was looking at just the trend line which has been very consistent for December 1st and would put it under 414. But others have noted the peak in April or May usually ends up pretty close to the December 1st value, and this year that value was well over 414 and exceeded the trend quite a bit. On the other hand though I took a look at September and October 1st, and September 1st is on trend but October 1st is over trend. But looking at the October 1st to December 1st gain each year, the years where October 1st is over trend appear to have lower gains from October to December. I'm thinking the data is a bit noisy and the trend is probably the most reliable. But the April-May peak matching fairly close with the December 1st value is leading me to be much less confident and it could go either way.

Having dug into the data in more detail, including the trend this year, the current level of PPM and it's trend so far suggests a level above 414 at the end of the year - most likely around 414.5. Even a correction such that the trend matches of that of the most recent low of the last 10 years (2011) would still result in a ppm by end year of 414.2. Also, while the lockdowns globally will reduce economic activity and, by extension, carbon emissions; that is somewhat offset by the likely increase in the use of cars as an alternative to public transport.
The numbers are not moving downward the way I expected. Not ready to predict over 416.
We are around the peak of the yearly cycle so above 416 is vanishingly unlikely but that 414 figure is still looking good, especially if lockdowns are lifted soon.

If emissions follow usual trajectory they'll drop around 7.5˚ as foliage absorbs CO2 then go up again with foliage reduction at the end of the year, however current record high may have several different combinations of causes and consequences, including the possibility that we won't see the usual absorption process this year and that emissions will remain high or possibly go even higher than the current level. This would be devastatingly bad news, but then the news we've hit a new high despite the massive drop in industry is devastating already. Meanwhile far-right leaders have used the pandemic to increase deforestation and carbon emitting industries, the bushfires have destroyed vast swathes of Australia's carbon sink, the ice caps have continued melting and so on. I regret taking my eye off the ball on this question because of other activities and am returning to something closer to my February position while allowing for an optimistic 5% in the 412-414 category in case the drop in industry has a delayed knock-on effect. I fear it's likelier that current effects, further fires, loss of the aerosol masking effect and so on keep the figure high, though.

Updating to add a couple observations based on the ESRL data: - Simple trends give a baseline of the December average breaking 414 PPM in 4/5 scenarios; - 1 December varies from December whole-month mean by an average of -0.127% (+/- .02); accounting for that brings some scenarios back down below 414 PPM; - At a quick look, profile of the 2020 numbers to date (based on month-month change) is dead on trend with the last 10 years; for the very little that it’s worth, thus far the 2020 profile resembles those of 2017 and 2013 more strongly than other recent years, and modifying the baseline with assumptions based on those years brings most scenarios back up well above 414 PPM; - Reaching either the 416 PPM and the 412 PPM levels would require sustained deviations from the average rate of change outside anything that seems likely, something on the order of the month-to-month rate of change running consistently 20-30% outside of normal, and always deviating in the same direction - not impossible certainly, but also not likely - odds run quite a bit less than 1/100; - In general, this CO2 number does not look very sensitive to short-term human changes. By my count, keeping the level below 414 PPM on 1 December from where we are now would require downward deviation of ~3-4% from average in the rate CO2 is added to the atmosphere (from all sources, not just human, and assuming that CO2 fixation during N hemisphere summer stays right on average); easily within the realm of natural variation, but a heavy lift indeed for human factors alone; - Quick look at the general outlook for northern hemisphere summer doesn’t give much reason to think that CO2 fixation will increase, but this is something that could have a dramatic impact on the probabilities; - One or more of the below would seriously change my estimate of the probabilities: - 1) Weather - N hemisphere (or ocean) having an unexpectedly productive (or poor) growing season; also, if one of the strong Nino/Nina effects comes into play (NOAA estimate is 60% chance of remaining in neutral Nino effect for this year), would have to look at effect of changing Pacific H2O temps on marine CO2 sequestration as well as effect on terrestrial growing season; - 2) Major natural CO2 emitting event; - 3) Strong deviations from expectation in NOAA CO2 observational data from coming months; - 4) Much stronger than expected change in human CO2 emissions because of... whatever might cause something this big (back of the envelope math suggests that absent significant movement in the natural factors, this would have to be REAL serious - something on the order of a 60% reduction).

The average for January 2020 was about 413.1ppm. Trends also show that CO2 measurements peak at around March each year and are at their lowest around December. In the past 5 years, the growth rate from January to December has averaged about 1.9. It should also be taken into account that historically, the growth rate drops for about 2 years following UN conferences or other signs of increased world interest in climate change, because of this, the 2.9-3+ ppm growth rate required to reach 416+ is unlikely for 2020. The growth rate will more likely resemble that of 2018 following the Paris Climate Agreement of 2017 and the value will be around 414.5-415.

Among the inputs my forecast is based on (ARIMA, ETS, UK Met office forecast on natural sinks), I am also incorporating @jtrommel's model results based on an STL approach.

I checked an STL-model using the historical record. The STL-predictions seem to be very robust, if slightly (on average -0.2 ppm) underestimating the observed value at December 1st. The seasonal pattern is very stable and the seasonally adjusted component is approximated with the Loess-method. This can cause the trend line to "wobble" a bit when new data become available and we get closer to the prediction date. This is the case with these data and in general the result is that when the CO2-value drops after the month of May, the STL-model tends to underpredict the value for December 1st. On average this is 0.2 ppm, so this is not critical given that the differences between the levels is 2 ppm. At present (2020-01-25) the prediction is 414.6 ppm with a sigma of 0.166 ppm. The region 414-416 seems the most likely.

With a starting point of 411.56 on January 18, 2020 and an increase projected along the same trajectory as has been seen since 2010, one could reasonably estimate the CO2 values for December 1, 2020 to lie between 411.77 ppm and 414.11 ppm. Confidence levels for the lower side of the range is very low and presumes significant action toward limiting climate change by the major world economies, including the US. As this has obviously not been the case the likelihood of the lower end of the scale is very low. The impact of the climate change related fires in Australia and other locations around the planet might accelerate CO2 values significantly, however no data is available to extrapolate so confidence levels are again kept very low. Modeling suggests the CO2 value will be very near or exceed 414 ppm by December 1, 2020, therefore I allocated the remaining probability evenly between the 2 choices that contain the 414 value.
Spreadsheet here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1r8Ko8I_KKMhG6-F14bUJ23Mz5-oewDh8pfLAYxNgaOI/edit?usp=sharing Linear regression gives point estimate just a hair under 414.

Less than 412 seems like it would require a recession in the US and China starting early in the year, which seems unlikely. China is slowing but the US seems to be going strong for now. 416 or more would be a major event that released a bunch of CO2 into the atmosphere. Not zero but unlikely at ~3 sigma .

The pattern of CO2 measurements around the globe show basically a combination of three signals; a long-term trend, a non-sinusoidal yearly cycle (note the yearly cycle is non-sinusoidal), and short term variations that can last from several hours to several weeks, which are due to local and regional influences. It has been shown that a second-degree polynomial plus 4 yearly harmonics model the long-term and seasonal variation of CO2 pretty well (1). I implemented this model and perform a least squares regression using the available data from NOAA (2). Implementation of the model is straightforward if you use the matrix approach.

I keep crunching the numbers on this one and continue to come up with something in the 414,5 - 415,0 range (larger hits at 414,5). Despite my own data (which only scratches surface complexity) still heavy on 412-414 range (call it naïve optimism).

I started with a linear regression of 10 days surrounding December 1 for every year in the data. I was surprised the coefficients for this model are very significant and the R-sq is 99%. Fitting the bins, there is a 93% chance of falling between 412 and 414ppm and 6% chance of falling between 414 and 416ppm. In order to be able to evolve my numbers in the course of the year, I also made an ETS model which resulted in a higher spread 31%,55%,13%,0%. I see that the crowd has come up with bigger numbers for the higher intervals, I'll check my methods again ... For now, I averaged the results of both models.
Now that we some 2020, I reran the model and got very similar predictions. Increasing my density in the 414-416 category by a little bit in response to the model making the same predictions.

The STL-model is in fact performing very well! I made a coding error which resulted in an apparent underprediction. This is now corrected. Linear regression model (trend + seasonal) or (trend + Fourier) are worse than the STL. ETS and ARIMA will be tried later.

Setting a base rate. Numbers for 2017, 2018, and 2019 were roughly 406.5, 409, and 411.5. Assuming 414 as a reasonable median forecast and maybe over a little more likely than under.

Checked my STL-model with the historical record and it showed that it consistently underestimated the observed values by about 2ppm. That does not seem much, but the margins of the question are in steps of 2ppm. I will shift my forecast to the higher values, but no so far as to put everything in the upper region, until I have a better idea why the model underpredicts. I was thinking about the Australian bushfires. But Wikipedia tells me that 1ppm is equivalent to 7.82Gtonnes of CO2 (7820Mtonnes). The bushfires in Australia add (on average) 380Mtonnes per year. If this doubles it would mean an extra 380Mtonnes or +0.05 ppm. Even if the damage is 10 times more than the yearly average it would only increase 0.5 ppm. This is not nothing, but not too large. Yet, it points towards an increase, so I am moving into the higher percentages.

Given the strong, consistent seasonality of the data I chose to go simple and use Triple Exponential Smoothing. I thought about using ARIMA and I see that several colleagues have chosen that. However, I find the simple smoothers work almost as good. I've been burned so many times by using a normal prediction interval that I used a variant of the Cauchy function to capture longer tails than the gaussian distribution. My results suggest that the cyclical data will be between 414 and 416 ppm at that time of the year.

What will be the Estimated CO2 (carbon dioxide) Daily Global Seasonal Cycle value for 1 December 2020, according to NOAA's Earth System Research Laboratory? Hattip to @petequinn and @Emil for their thoughtful analysis. And I sincerely hope my Brier gets killed by my overly pessimistic estimate.

I've spent a fair bit more time on this today, running in circles to a large degree. It would be very difficult for me to easily explain how I've landed on this split, but it is based on a certain logic and I can update it at any particular day over the next year by comparing how the actual daily value is tracking against my linear and polynomial best fit projections. Accounting for actuals early in the new year, I'm getting a projection of 13.95 from my slightly weaker linear best fit and 14.24 from my polynomial best fit. If I give the two "best fits" equal weight, I land on the polynomial projection having about 5 times more likelihood (+0.24) than the linear one (-0.5), which I've rounded to 85/15.

One way to approach this is statistically since we have good data. Particularly suitable is time series modeling that extends past trend and seasonality to estimate future values. Specifically I use an autoregressive integrated moving average modeling with seasonality.

Changing my mind. When I use the linear best fit with the same general approach, I get a most likely value of 413.64, and 6% chance (based on variability of nine years' date from the linear best fit) to be above 414.0. So One result gives me 94% chance of being below 414, the other gives me 96% chance being above. This is basically a draw, with a slight tip in favour of > 414.
I'm gonna go all in based on the strength of the result I described previously, what the heck, roll the dice... yippee!

This is a tricky one, because our ability to predict won't improve as time draws closer. The data have strong annual variation. I've plotted the values for 1 December each year and then drawn a second order polynomial best fit (I started with linear and got R^2 ~ 0.983, then moved to the polynomial and got 0.999). I then used that best fit to project to 1 December 2020, and get a most likely value of 414.299. However, the variability between actual values and the best fit ranges between - 0.346 to + 0.372, and I get + 0.299 (the amount needed to get below 414.0) has a percentile rank of about 2.5%, which means a 3% probability, based on a naïve look at the data. Typing 4% in my forecast rather than 3 was a typo.

The patterns of the trend and seasonality are very steady. Decomposing the data and using a random walk drift model I get these results. December 1st 2020 lies on a very steep part of the curve but in previous years this part was very steady. However: the limits (412, 414, 416) in this question are VERY close together. I will need to find out how this model would have worked in the past. I have no idea if events like the spectacular fires in Australia have an impact on these measurements.

@Emil @Anneinak @danielharan Thank you all for the suggestions. I've revised a bit and updated my predictions a bit. I now make my methods a little more clear.

So, in 10 years we've added 355.1 gigatonnes in the atmosphere, and the CO2 concentration has increased by 24.43 ppm? Let's say we add another 37.2 gigatonnes this coming year... that gets us to 414.01 ppm, right in the middle of the options.

Setting priors: The most likely event that will have a significant downward effect on the rate of CO² increase would be a global recession. The 2007-8 crisis flattened the curve but in this case, it would have to be early in the year to have that outcome in 2020. In the absence of an economic downturn, business-as-usual would result in a figure straddling the 414 mark, with a tendency to be slightly over. Another factor to take into consideration is the passing of a significant tipping point, which would increase the rate of CO² emmissions by an incalculable amount, but taking us over the 416 level.

I see two challenges with this question. First, predicting a series that displays a broad trend (upward sloping) but also cycles. The cycles seem to peak in early May and reach their minimum in late August. The cycles are very constant over time. The trend also seems pretty constant, but may be increasing as global warming becomes more and more of a problem.
